name: Diamond
description:
Diamond is not only a girl's best friend but also the hardest naturally occurring substance known to man. Originating deep within the Earth's mantle under extreme heat and pressure, it's essentially just carbon. When perfectly cut, it brilliantly refracts light, making it a sought-after gem in jewelry. Additionally, due to its hardness, it's crucial in various industrial applications.

*Fun Fact:* Did you know that diamonds can come in various colors, including blue, green, and even pink?

Check out [More about Diamonds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond)!

name: Quartz
description:
One of the Earth's most abundant minerals, quartz is renowned for its durability and versatility. This gemstone can be found in various hues and is often used in jewelry and timepieces. Beyond its beauty, it has significant technological applications, being a key component in modern electronics like watches, radios, and computers.

*Did You Know?* Quartz crystals have the property of piezoelectricity, meaning they can convert mechanical energy into electrical energy!

Explore [More about Quartz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartz)!

name: Topaz
description:
A gemstone that captures the essence of sunny skies and golden sunsets, topaz is cherished for its range of vibrant colors. From transparent to blue, and the coveted Imperial Topaz with its golden hue, this gem is a favorite among jewelry enthusiasts. In ancient times, it was believed to provide strength and intelligence.

*Did You Know?* The name 'topaz' is derived from the Greek word 'Τοpáziοs', which stems from an island in the Red Sea where the gem was once mined.

Discover [More about Topaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topaz)!

name: Sapphire
description:
Known as the gem of the heavens, sapphire is celebrated for its brilliant blue hues but can come in a rainbow of colors—except red. Prized by royalty and symbolizing wisdom, virtue, and good fortune, sapphires are the birthstone for September.

*Did You Know?* Sapphires, when they exhibit a star-like pattern due to their inclusions, are known as 'Star Sapphires'.

Discover [More about Sapphire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sapphire)!

name: Opal
description:
Opal, known for its dazzling play of colors, is a symbol of hope, innocence, and purity. Unlike many other gemstones, each opal is truly unique. Its water content causes its mesmerizing play of color.

*Did You Know?* The name 'Opal' originates from the Sanskrit word 'upala', meaning 'precious stone'.

Discover [More about Opal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opal)!

name: Sand
description:
Ubiquitous and transformative, sand is a sedimentary rock characterized by its fine granules. It spans across various regions, taking on unique colors that paint vast deserts, serene beaches, and boundless dunes. Not just a natural wonder, sand plays a crucial role in construction, manufacturing, and even time-telling through hourglasses.

*Did You Know?* While often associated with beaches and deserts, sand can also be found in unique locations like the ocean floor and even inside certain living organisms like parrotfish, who produce sand as a byproduct of their feeding habits.

Discover [More about Sand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sand)!

name: Amber
description:
Amber, known for its warm, golden hues, is not a mineral in the traditional sense, but rather fossilized tree resin. Revered since ancient times for its beauty and used to create jewelry, amulets, and decorative items, amber often encapsulates small insects and other inclusions, making it a window into the prehistoric world. Due to its organic origin, it's softer than many gemstones and requires care to prevent scratching.

*Fun Fact:* Under UV light, amber can produce a strong fluorescence, and its colors can range from the familiar gold to blue and even black.

Check out [More about Amber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber)!

name: Emerald
description:
Emerald, renowned for its radiant green hue, belongs to the beryl family of minerals. This gemstone has been treasured for millennia, symbolizing rebirth and love. Often associated with the lush landscapes of Ireland and the birthstone for May, emeralds are a cornerstone in high-quality jewelry, especially when they exhibit a vivid green color and good transparency. Due to its inclusions and fractures, emeralds can be fragile and require special care when worn or set in jewelry.

*Fun Fact:* The word 'emerald' is derived from the ancient Greek word for green, 'smaragdus'.

Check out [More about Emerald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emerald)!

name: Azurite
description:
Azurite is a stunning deep blue copper mineral that has been cherished since ancient times for its vibrant color. Often found in association with malachite, it has been utilized as a blue pigment for paintings and dyes for centuries.

*Fun Fact:* In ancient Egypt, azurite was often used in cosmetics and as a blue pigment for various artworks.

Check out [More about Azurite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azurite)!

name: Molybdenite
description:
Molybdenite is a very soft, silvery-gray mineral primarily composed of molybdenum and sulfur. It's the main source of molybdenum, which is used in various industrial applications, including the manufacture of stainless steel. It can be found in granite veins in many parts of the world.

*Fun Fact:* Due to its similarity to graphite, molybdenite is sometimes used as a lubricant.

[Learn more about Molybdenite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molybdenite)!

name: Malachite
description:
Malachite is a vibrant green mineral that is often used as a gemstone and for ornamental purposes. It is primarily composed of copper carbonate hydroxide. Historically, it was used as a source of copper and in pigments, and today, it is often carved into jewelry and decorative objects.

*Fun Fact:* Malachite is believed to have protective properties, often worn to guard against negative energies.

[Learn more about Malachite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malachite)!

name: Pyrite
description:
Often referred to as 'Fool's Gold' because of its metallic luster and pale brass-yellow hue, Pyrite is a very common iron sulfide mineral. While it has been historically used as a source of ignition in early firearms due to its ability to strike sparks when hit against metal, today, it's often found in ornamental pieces and jewelry.

*Fun Fact:* Despite its nickname as 'Fool's Gold', experienced miners and geologists can easily distinguish pyrite from real gold because pyrite is not malleable and shatters easily.

[Read more about Pyrite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyrite)!

name: Tourmaline
description:
Tourmaline is a captivating boron silicate mineral that occurs in a myriad of colors, sometimes even multi-colored within the same crystal. Its vibrant hues and piezoelectric properties have made it a favorite among jewelers and collectors. This mineral is unique because when it's heated or pressure is applied, it can become electrically charged. This phenomenon led to its use in early pressure measuring devices.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'tourmaline' comes from the Sinhalese term 'turmali', which was a term used for different gemstones found in Sri Lanka.

[Read more about Tourmaline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourmaline)!
occurrences: worldwide, notably in Brazil, Afghanistan, East Africa, and the USA

name: Fluorite
description:
Fluorite, also known as fluorspar, is a colorful mineral composed of calcium and fluorine. It's renowned for its stunning range of colors and its ability to fluoresce under ultraviolet light — a property that actually gave the name to the phenomenon of fluorescence. Fluorite is significant not only for collectors but also industrially as a flux for smelting, and in the production of certain glasses and enamels.

*Fun Fact:* The word 'fluorescence' is derived from 'fluorite', the mineral that demonstrated this effect so vividly.

[Read more about Fluorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluorite)!
cleavage: perfect in four directions forming octahedra
occurrences: worldwide, notably in China, Mexico, South Africa, and the USA

name: Garnet
description:
Garnet is not a single mineral but describes a group of several closely related minerals. Garnets come in a variety of colors, but the most commonly known is the dark red variety. This gemstone has been cherished for millennia, used both as jewelry and as an abrasive in industry. It's popularly associated with love, passion, and energy, and is the birthstone for January.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'garnet' comes from the Latin word 'granatus', which means seed, because of the gemstone's resemblance to a pomegranate seed.

[Discover more about Garnet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garnet)!
chemicalFormula: General formula X3Y2(SiO4)3 where X and Y are various ions.
crystals: dodecahedra or trapezohedra, commonly granular or massive
occurrences: worldwide, notably in India, Russia, Turkey, and the USA

name: Calcite
description:
Calcite is a common and widespread carbonate mineral. It is the primary component of limestone and marble. This mineral exhibits a remarkable diversity of crystal shapes and can appear in numerous colors or remain transparent. Calcite reacts with acid, producing bubbles of CO2, a property used to test and identify calcite. It has a significant role in the Earth's carbon cycle and has been instrumental in forming many of the Earth's sedimentary rocks.

*Fun Fact:* Calcite's more transparent varieties are used to create optical lenses, including those for microscopes.

[More about Calcite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcite)!
cleavage: perfect in three directions, producing rhombohedra

name: Galena
description:
Galena is the primary ore of lead and is often mined for its silver content as well. It is a heavy, grayish-black mineral with a metallic luster and a cubic crystalline structure. Due to its high density and metallic luster, it's easily recognized in the field. Ancient civilizations used galena as a cosmetic, as a source of lead, and also recognized its use in producing silver.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'Galena' is derived from the Latin word for lead ore.

[More about Galena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galena)!

name: Lepidolite
description:
Lepidolite is a lilac-gray or rose-colored member of the mica group of minerals and is the most abundant lithium-bearing mineral. Known for its vibrant purple and pink hues, it's often used as a gemstone or ornamental stone. Beyond its aesthetic appeal, Lepidolite is sometimes used as a minor ore of lithium, which is an essential component in rechargeable batteries.

*Fun Fact:* Lepidolite is considered by many to be a 'stone of transition' helping individuals through challenging times.

[More about Lepidolite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lepidolite)!
crystals: tabular, can be massive or granular

name: Beryl
description:
Beryl is a mineral composed of beryllium aluminium cyclosilicate, with the chemical formula Be₃Al₂(SiO₃)₆. Its color can vary from green (emerald), blue to blue-green (aquamarine), yellow-green (heliodor), yellow, red (like morganite), and can be both colorless or white. Beryl is often used as a gemstone, with its different colors attributed to various trace elements. Emerald and aquamarine are two of the most popular and valuable Beryl gemstones.

*Fun Fact:* Pure beryl is colorless, but it can take on various colors depending on impurities in its structure.

[More about Beryl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beryl)!

name: Hematite
description:
Hematite is a common iron oxide mineral with the formula Fe₂O₃. It is known for its signature metallic luster and reddish-brown color. Hematite is an important ore of iron and has been used for several purposes, ranging from decoration to etching into ancient petroglyphs. When used as a gemstone, hematite is often polished to a high sheen. Hematite's red streak is one of its distinguishing characteristics.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'hematite' is derived from the Greek word for blood, 'haima', due to the red streak it produces when scratched against a harder material.

[More about Hematite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hematite)!

name: Chrysocolla
description:
Chrysocolla is a vibrant blue-green copper mineral that often forms in association with Malachite and Azurite. It has a unique, attractive color that makes it a favorite among gem and mineral collectors. Historically, it has been used by various cultures as a pigment, and its color was prized by the ancient Egyptians. In the realm of metaphysical properties, Chrysocolla is often associated with tranquility and peace, communication, and connection to the subconscious.

*Fun Fact:* Despite its beautiful appearance, Chrysocolla is relatively soft, which makes it challenging to use in traditional jewelry settings.

[More about Chrysocolla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysocolla)!

name: Gypsum
description:
Gypsum is a soft sulfate mineral composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate. It is widely mined and is commonly used in construction, especially in the form of plaster, wallboard, and cement. Gypsum is also utilized in agriculture as a fertilizer and soil conditioner due to its high calcium content. The crystal variety of gypsum, known as 'selenite', can be quite large, and some of the largest crystals in the world are found to be gypsum crystals.

*Fun Fact:* When heated, gypsum releases water and hardens into plaster of Paris, a material used for sculptures and molds.

[More about Gypsum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gypsum)!

name: Obsidian
description:
Obsidian is a naturally occurring volcanic glass formed from rapidly cooled lava with high silica content. It is often used for ornamental purposes because of its glassy appearance. Due to its sharp edges when broken, obsidian was historically used by many cultures to produce sharp tools, weapons, and ornaments. Its colors can range based on the presence of impurities, with black being the most common, but it can also be brown or green, and occasionally, red or blue.

*Fun Fact:* Snowflake obsidian, which has splotches that look like snowflakes, is created when the mineral cristobalite is included in the obsidian.

[More about Obsidian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obsidian)!

name: Kyanite
description:
Kyanite is an aluminum silicate mineral that's best known for its blue color, though it can also be green, white, yellow, or gray. It is typically used as an index mineral in the metamorphism of clay-rich sediments. A remarkable characteristic of kyanite is its variable hardness, which depends on the direction along which it's tested. It's harder across the shorter axis and softer along the length.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'kyanite' is derived from the Greek word 'kyanos' meaning blue, owing to its most common hue.

[More about Kyanite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyanite)!

name: Sodalite
description:
Sodalite is a rich royal blue mineral widely enjoyed as an ornamental gemstone. Although massive sodalite samples are opaque, crystals are usually transparent to translucent. It's a member of the sodalite group and shares similarities with lapis lazuli. Apart from its beauty, sodalite can also be used in ceramics and glasses, especially when a blue color is desired.

*Fun Fact:* It was named after its sodium content, and during the 1800s, it was often termed as 'princess blue' after Princess Patricia chose it as an interior decoration for the Marlborough House in England.

[More about Sodalite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sodalite)!

name: Talc
description:
Talc is the softest mineral known to man, often used to produce talcum powder. It has a soapy or greasy feel, which led to the mineral being named after the Arabic word for soap. Talc is also used in a variety of other products, including ceramics, paint, paper, and even some food items.

*Fun Fact:* Due to its resistance to heat, electricity, and acids, it's an important ingredient in industries ranging from cosmetics to ceramics.

[More about Talc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talc)!

name: Muscovite
description:
Muscovite, also known as common mica, is a member of the mica group of sheet silicate minerals. It splits into thin sheets and is commonly used as window panes in older buildings and specialized applications like oven windows due to its heat-resistant properties. The name 'Muscovite' comes from 'Muscovy-glass', a name formerly used for the mineral in Russia because of its use in windows.

*Fun Fact:* It's sometimes called the 'window pane' mineral because of its use in making transparent sheets for early windows.

[More about Muscovite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscovite)!

name: Spinel
description:
Spinel is a beautiful gemstone that often gets mistaken for ruby or sapphire because of its range of brilliant colors. These vibrant gems are composed of magnesium aluminate, and they can be found in a variety of shades, including red, blue, and violet. Historically, some famous 'rubies' in crown jewels have turned out to be spinels.

*Fun Fact:* The Black Prince’s Ruby and the Timur Ruby, which are part of the British Crown Jewels, were once thought to be rubies but are actually large red spinels.

[More about Spinel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spinel)!

name: Cinnabar
description:
Cinnabar is a bright red mineral, primarily used historically as a pigment due to its vivid color. It is also the main ore of mercury. The mineral can be found near volcanic activity and hot springs. It has a non-metallic luster and is identified by its red streak. Though beautiful, cinnabar can be toxic to humans due to the presence of mercury.

*Fun Fact:* Cinnabar was used by ancient civilizations as a red pigment in pottery, murals, and in cosmetics. Even today, in some parts of the world, cinnabar is used in cultural and religious ceremonies.

[More about Cinnabar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinnabar)!

name: Turquoise
description:
Turquoise is a blue to green mineral that has been prized for millennia as an ornamental stone. Its stunning color is due to the presence of copper. Used in ancient jewelry, masks, and more, it was often considered a symbol of wealth and status among many ancient civilizations, including the Egyptians and Native Americans.

*Fun Fact:* The word turquoise comes from 'Turkish', as the mineral was originally imported to Europe through Turkey from mines in the historical Khorasan of Persia.

[More about Turquoise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turquoise)!

name: Zircon
description:
Zircon is a mineral belonging to the group of nesosilicates. Its chemical name is zirconium silicate, and its color can vary from colorless (which is used as a diamond simulator in jewelry) to brown, yellow, green, and even red. Zircon has been used for thousands of years in various applications, from decorative gemstones to applications in the nuclear industry due to its ability to resist radiation.

*Fun Fact:* The oldest minerals on Earth, with ages of up to 4.4 billion years, are zircons from Western Australia.

[More about Zircon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zircon)!

name: Andalusite
description:
Andalusite is an aluminum nesosilicate mineral named after Andalusia, the region in Spain where it was first described. This mineral is known for its distinctive cross-shaped appearance when it is cut, which is called 'chiastolite'. It changes into kyanite and sillimanite at varying temperature-pressure conditions, making it valuable for studying metamorphic reactions.

*Fun Fact:* Some varieties of andalusite can change colors depending on the angle of light, making it a unique gemstone.

[More about Andalusite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andalusite)!

name: Apatite
description:
Apatite is a group of phosphate minerals that include hydroxylapatite, fluorapatite, and chlorapatite. While often unrecognized by the general public, apatite is the main source of phosphorus for the global agricultural fertilizer industry. Due to its vibrant colors, it's also occasionally used as a gemstone, though it's relatively soft compared to other gemstones.

*Fun Fact:* The name apatite is derived from the Greek word 'apate', meaning 'deceit', because of its similar appearance to several other minerals.

[More about Apatite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apatite)!

name: Peridot
description:
Peridot is the gem-quality variety of the mineral olivine. It's one of the few gemstones that occur in only one color, an olive-green. The intensity of the green depends on how much iron is present in the crystal structure, so the color can vary from yellow-green to olive to brownish-green. Historically, peridot gemstones are believed to possess healing properties that protect against nightmares and bring the wearer power, influence, and a wonderful year.

*Fun Fact:* Peridot is sometimes called 'evening emerald' because of its shimmering under artificial light.

[More about Peridot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peridot)!

name: Labradorite
description:
Labradorite is a feldspar mineral that is most often found in mafic igneous rocks. It's renowned for its striking play of color, often exhibiting vibrant flashes of blue, green, red, orange, and yellow. These colorful flashes change depending on the angle of view, a phenomenon known as labradorescence. Labradorite was first identified in Labrador, Canada, which is where it gets its name.

*Fun Fact:* Labradorite has become a popular gemstone because of its unique and beautiful iridescent play of colors.

[More about Labradorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labradorite)!

name: Rhodonite
description:
Rhodonite is a manganese silicate mineral with a triclinic crystal system. It is pink to red in color with black dendritic inclusions. It is often confused with rhodochrosite because of their similar appearances and names. Rhodonite is typically found in metamorphic rocks and is also considered a gemstone, being cut into cabochons and beads for jewelry use.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'rhodonite' comes from the Greek word 'rhodos', meaning 'rose', due to its pinkish color.

[More about Rhodonite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhodonite)!

name: The Rock
description:
The Rock, also known as Dwayne Douglas Johnson, is not a mineral, but a larger-than-life actor and former professional wrestler. Born on May 2, 1972, in Hayward, California, he became famous in the wrestling world under his ring name 'The Rock'. Transitioning to Hollywood, he became one of the biggest box office draws in the world. While not found in any rock formations, he is commonly found in blockbuster movies and occasionally 'laying the smackdown'.

*Fun Fact:* 'Can you smell what The Rock is cooking?' is one of his iconic catchphrases.

[More about The Rock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwayne_Johnson)!
chemicalFormula: C6H12O6 (because he's sweet and full of energy!)
hardness: On a scale of 1 to 10? Definitely 11.

name: Jadeite
description:
Jadeite is one of the minerals that is recognized as the gemstone jade (the other is nephrite). It's often green, but can also be blue-green, lavender, pink, or even white. Jadeite is prized for its hardness and for its beauty, especially in East Asian cultures. It's typically used for carving intricate jewelry, beads, and figurines.

*Fun Fact:* Jadeite's value is determined largely by its color, with the intense, emerald-green color being the most valuable.

[More about Jadeite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadeite)!

name: Feldspar
description:
Feldspar is a group of rock-forming tectosilicate minerals that make up about 41% of the Earth's continental crust by weight. Feldspars crystallize from magma in both intrusive and extrusive igneous rocks, as veins, and are also present in many types of metamorphic rock.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'feldspar' derives from the German 'Feldspat', a compound of the words Feld ('field') and Spat ('flake'). Feldspar has been used as a raw material for pottery and glass making due to its alumina and alkali content.

[More about Feldspar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feldspar)
crystals: Generally blocky or elongated and tabular

name: Magnetite
description:
Magnetite is one of the most common iron minerals and an important ore of iron. It's black or brownish-black with a metallic luster and belongs to the spinel group of minerals. A unique property of magnetite is its strong magnetism, which makes it one of just a few minerals that are attracted to a common magnet.

*Fun Fact:* It's believed that migratory birds and other animals might use the Earth's magnetic field for navigation, which is influenced by magnetite deposits.

[More about Magnetite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetite)

name: Halite
description:
Halite, commonly known as rock salt, is a type of salt, the mineral form of sodium chloride (NaCl). It forms isometric crystals and is typically colorless or white, but can also be light blue, dark blue, purple, pink, red, orange, yellow, or gray depending on the amount and type of impurities. It's frequently used for salt in cooking and as a road deicer.

*Fun Fact:* Inhaling air from salt mines has been claimed to benefit respiratory diseases, leading to the establishment of salt therapy locations worldwide.

[More about Halite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halite)

name: Covellite
description:
Covellite is a rare copper sulfide mineral that is known for its deep indigo-blue color, which can appear almost black. It forms hexagonal crystals and is typically associated with other copper sulfides in the supergene environment of copper deposits.

*Fun Fact:* Covellite is a significant ore of copper and is also used as a mineral specimen and gemstone.

[More about Covellite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covellite)

name: Stibnite
description:
Stibnite is a sulfide mineral composed of antimony (Sb) and sulfur (S). It is the primary source of the element antimony. Typically, stibnite forms sharp elongated crystals that are silvery-gray but can tarnish to a black hue. It is very soft, easily scratched by a fingernail. It has a brilliant metallic luster and was historically used as a cosmetic in ancient civilizations.

*Fun Fact:* Stibnite's name is derived from the latin 'stibium', which is the old name of the element antimony.

[More about Stibnite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stibnite)

name: Wulfenite
description:
Wulfenite is a lead molybdate mineral with the formula PbMoO₄. It is known for its vibrant color palette that ranges from bright orange to deep red. Wulfenite forms in the oxidized zone of hydrothermal lead deposits, often associated with lead and zinc. It crystallizes in the tetragonal system, producing thin tabular crystals. Due to its striking appearance and bright colors, it is highly prized by mineral collectors.

*Fun Fact:* Its name honors Austrian mineralogist Franz Xavier von Wulfen who wrote extensively about the mineral in the 18th century.

[More about Wulfenite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wulfenite)

name: Corundum
description:
Corundum is a rock-forming mineral known for its hardness and is often used as an abrasive. It is the crystalline form of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃) and can have various colors, depending on impurities. Red varieties of corundum are known as rubies, while all other colors are sapphires, with the blue sapphire being the most well-known.

*Fun Fact:* Corundum is the second hardest natural mineral, following diamond, and has a rating of 9 on the Mohs scale.

[More about Corundum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corundum)

name: Smithsonite
description:
Smithsonite, formerly known as calamine, is a zinc carbonate mineral and a member of the calcite group. Its crystal structure is rhombohedral, similar to that of calcite. It forms in oxidized zinc ore deposits and can occur in a variety of colors, including blue-green, pink, purple, and yellow, depending on impurities.

*Fun Fact:* Smithsonite was named in honor of James Smithson, the founder of the Smithsonian Institution.

[More about Smithsonite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smithsonite)

name: Baryte
description:
Baryte (or Barite) is a mineral consisting of barium sulfate (BaSO4). Barite is generally white or colorless, and is the main source of the element barium.

*Fun Fact:* Barite's high density makes it opaque to X-rays, and it is used in cement to block X-ray emissions in hospitals, power plants, and laboratories.

[More about Barite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baryte)
colors: light shades of blue, green, yellow

name: Chalcopyrite
description:
Chalcopyrite is a brass-yellow mineral with a chemical composition of CuFeS2. It occurs in most sulfide mineral deposits throughout the world and has been the most important ore of copper for thousands of years.

*Fun Fact:* Despite its bright and attractive color, chalcopyrite is rarely used as a gem because of its relatively low hardness and cleavage.

[More about Chalcopyrite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chalcopyrite)

name: Orthoclase
description:
Orthoclase is an important tectosilicate mineral that forms igneous rock. It's a type of potassium feldspar, commonly found in granites, syenites, and monzonites. It is also found in many types of sedimentary and metamorphic rocks. Despite its widespread presence, it's rarely used as a gem due to its relative fragility. The name 'Orthoclase' is derived from the Greek word 'Orthos' which means 'right' and 'Klasis' which means 'fracture', referring to the mineral's cleavage.

[More about Orthoclase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthoclase)
cleavage: Good in two directions forming nearly right angles

name: Dolomite
description:
Dolomite is an anhydrous carbonate mineral composed of calcium magnesium carbonate, ideally CaMg(CO₃)₂. It's used as a source of magnesia, a feed additive for livestock, a sintering agent and flux in metal processing, and also in the production of glass, bricks, and ceramics. Dolomite also serves as an oil and gas reservoir rock. The term 'dolomite' is used both for the mineral and for sedimentary rock made predominantly of the mineral.

[More about Dolomite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolomite_(mineral))
cleavage: Perfect in three directions forming rhombohedra

name: Celestine
description:
Celestine or celestite is a mineral consisting of strontium sulfate (SrSO4). It is typically blue, but can also be colorless, white, green, or brown. The mineral is named for its occasional delicate blue color.

*Fun Fact:* Celestine is the principal source of the element strontium, commonly used in fireworks and in various metal alloys.

[More about Celestine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celestine_(mineral))
cleavage: Perfect in one direction, good in two others

name: Goethite
description:
Goethite is an iron oxyhydroxide mineral, which is one of the main iron ores. In addition to being a significant ore of iron, goethite is also well known for its aesthetic black, brown to yellow forms found in many high-quality minerals and crystal specimens.

*Fun Fact:* Goethite has been used as a pigment for paints and is the source of the yellow in the famous ochre paints.

[More about Goethite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goethite)

name: Olivine
description:
Olivine is one of the most common minerals in the Earth's mantle but is very rare at the Earth's surface. It's named for its typically olive-green color, though it may alter to a reddish color from the oxidation of iron. Olivine is also found in meteorites and is sometimes considered as a gemstone.

*Fun Fact:* Some beaches, such as Papakōlea Beach in Hawaii, have green sands because of the high olivine content.

[More about Olivine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivine)

name: Augite
description:
Augite is a common rock-forming pyroxene mineral found in mafic and intermediate rocks. It's notable for its characteristic dark color and short prismatic crystals. Augite has a chemical composition that can vary significantly among specimens and has been studied extensively for its significance in geothermobarometry.

*Fun Fact:* Augite can sometimes be found in lunar basalts, indicating the moon has volcanic activity similar to certain conditions on Earth.

[More about Augite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augite)
cleavage: Good in two directions at 90 degrees

name: Aragonite
description:
Aragonite is a carbonate mineral, one of the two most common, naturally occurring crystal forms of calcium carbonate, the other being calcite. Aragonite differs from calcite in its crystal structure and various physical properties. It is commonly found in sedimentary and metamorphic rocks and can also be formed in various biological processes.

*Fun Fact:* The famous 'Cave of the Crystals' in Mexico features some of the world's largest natural crystals, which are made of aragonite.

[More about Aragonite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aragonite)

name: Sphalerite
description:
Sphalerite is a zinc sulfide mineral and is the primary ore of zinc. It has a wide range of colors and is often associated with galena, pyrite, and other sulfides. Sphalerite is known for its exceptional dispersion, which results in gem-quality stones displaying a brilliant fire similar to diamonds.

*Fun Fact:* Despite its beauty, gem-quality sphalerite is rarely used in jewelry due to its softness and sensitivity to light, which can cause it to darken over time.

[More about Sphalerite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphalerite)

name: Mimetite
description:
Mimetite is a lead arsenate chloride mineral that forms as a secondary mineral in lead deposits, usually by the oxidation of galena and arsenopyrite. Its vibrant yellow or orange-yellow color is quite distinctive, and it is often associated with wulfenite and pyromorphite. Mimetite can be prismatic to acicular and has a resinous luster.

*Fun Fact:* The name 'Mimetite' is derived from the Greek word 'mimetes', meaning 'imitator', referring to mimetite's close resemblance to pyromorphite.

[More about Mimetite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mimetite)

name: Grossular
description:
Grossular is a calcium-aluminium species of the garnet group of minerals. It has a chemical composition of Ca3Al2(SiO4)3. Grossular can be found in a range of colors including green, orange, and pink, but it is commonly colorless. The name 'grossular' is derived from the botanical name for the gooseberry, which is 'grossularia', reflecting the green color of some specimens.

*Fun Fact:* One of the most sought-after varieties of grossular is the vibrant green Tsavorite, which is found primarily in Tanzania and Kenya and is often used as a gemstone due to its striking color and clarity.

[More about Grossular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grossular)

name: Albite
description:
Albite is a plagioclase feldspar mineral. It is the sodium endmember of the plagioclase solid solution series. As such it represents a plagioclase with less than 10% anorthite content. The pure albite endmember has the formula NaAlSi3O8. It is a tectosilicate. Its color is usually pure white, hence its name from Latin 'albus'. It is a common constituent in felsic rocks.

*Fun Fact:* Moonstone, a beautiful and often iridescent gemstone, is actually a variety of albite!

[More about Albite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albite)

name: Actinolite
description:
Actinolite is a member of a series that contains varying amounts of iron and magnesium. Tremolite is the Mg end, and ferroactinolite the Fe end, with actinolite in the middle. Actinolites with more than 50% Fe are very rare. The name actinolite is derived from the Greek word 'aktinos', meaning 'ray' or 'spoke of a wheel', in reference to the mineral's radiated crystal habit.

*Fun Fact:* Actinolite is commonly found in metamorphic rocks, such as contact aureoles surrounding cooled intrusive igneous rocks. It also forms under high-pressure in blueschist facies metamorphism.

[More about Actinolite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actinolite)
